name: Dwida (Spicy Pasta Soup)
name_origin: The name 'Dwida' (دويدة) is the diminutive form of the Arabic word 'Doud' (دود), which means 'worm'. Therefore, 'Dwida' literally translates to 'little worm'. This follows a very common cross-cultural naming convention for thin pasta shapes (compare to Italian 'Vermicelli', which also means 'little worms'). In Tunisian cuisine, the term specifically refers to very thin pasta or vermicelli. While the specific recipe provided uses broken spaghetti, the name is retained because it mimics the shape of the traditional vermicelli used in this dish.
description: A traditional Tunisian pasta dish cooked in a spicy red tomato broth. While 'Dwida' typically refers to vermicelli, this specific family recipe uses spaghetti broken into pieces. It is a comfort food similar to Mhamsa but with a different pasta shape.
cultural_context: A staple of Djerban Jewish cuisine. The recipe notes explicitly link it to 'Mhamsa' (couscous/ptitim soup) and 'Shmid', indicating it shares the same foundational red spicy broth common in Tunisian cooking.

ingredients.name: Spaghetti
ingredients.notes: Can substitute with vermicelli or angel hair

ingredients.name: Vegetable oil
ingredients.notes: Olive oil is recommended for better flavor

ingredients.name: Garlic
ingredients.notes: Added to enhance the savory base

steps.instruction: In a pot, heat the oil and sauté the tomatoes and hot pepper until softened.
Add the paprika and salt, stirring briefly to release the aroma without burning the spices.
Add the water and bring the broth to a rolling boil.
Add the broken spaghetti pieces to the boiling broth.
steps.tips: The original recipe notes to prepare this exactly like 'Mhamsa' or 'Shmid', just swapping the grain for spaghetti.

steps.instruction: Cook until the pasta is tender and the sauce has thickened slightly.

variants.name: Traditional Dwida
variants.description: Use vermicelli (angel hair) pasta instead of spaghetti.

name_etymology.notes: Standard Maghrebi culinary terminology. The morphological pattern (Fu'ayla) is a standard Arabic diminutive form (e.g., 'Doud' becomes 'Dwida').

alternative_names.name: Douida
alternative_names.notes: Common French colonial transliteration found in Tunisian cookbooks

alternative_names.name: Dwida Jariya
alternative_names.notes: Literally 'Runny Dwida' - distinguishing the soup version from the steamed version (Dwida Mfawra)

alternative_names.name: Fdaouech
alternative_names.notes: A synonym often used in Tunisia for vermicelli or angel hair pasta

similar_dishes.name: Vermicelli in Broth
similar_dishes.similarity: Identical etymology (verme = worm) and pasta shape
similar_dishes.key_difference: Italian versions usually use chicken broth/clear broth; Tunisian Dwida uses a spicy tomato concentrate (harissa) base

similar_dishes.name: Sopa de Fideos
similar_dishes.similarity: Short thin pasta cooked in a tomato-based broth
similar_dishes.key_difference: Spicing profile (Tunisian uses caraway, coriander, and harissa)

similar_dishes.name: Dwida Mfawra
similar_dishes.key_difference: Mfawra is steamed (like couscous) and often served sweet with nuts or savory with meat, rather than as a soup

similar_dishes.name: Chorba
similar_dishes.similarity: The spicy red soup base is nearly identical
similar_dishes.key_difference: Chorba typically uses frik (green wheat) or barley, whereas Dwida uses pasta

intro_paragraph: Dwida translates to little worm in Arabic which refers to the vermicelli shape. This spicy Tunisian soup uses broken spaghetti cooked in a rich tomato broth. It is a warming comfort food from Djerban Jewish cuisine that shares a savory base with Mhamsa and is naturally plant-based.
